description: A common prefix or root "hom" in words, often with varied suffixes, carrying different meanings, such as "home", "homogeneous", "homology", "homemaker", "homeless", "homophobic", "homosexuality", "homicide", and others.

Words ending in suffixes indicating a material property or quality such as "proof", "resistant", "retardant", "impermeable", "invulnerable", "reflective", "breathable", "opaque", "stainless", "kosher", "impenetrable", "thermostable", "rugged", "airtight", "watertight", "flammable", "homophobic", "NSFW", indicating that a material object or substance has a specific characteristic or ability.

Texts discussing bullying, including various forms of bullying such as cyberbullying, homophobic bullying, and teasing, as well as mentions of bullies, bully victims, and anti-bullying policies and initiatives.
The token "gay" often appears, and it frequently co-occurs with words like "homosexuality", "homosexual", "homophobic", and "same-sex", indicating a focus on LGBTQ+ themes and issues.

A wide range of words or phrases that express strong or emphatic positive or negative reactions, descriptions, or conditions, often related to abilities, circumstances, or characteristics, and frequently taking the form of adjectives, nouns, or adverbs with distinctive suffixes or prefixes (e.g. "phenomenal", "phenomenon", "phenom", "horrrendous", "fabulously", "commendable", "abysmal", "hysterical", "homophobic", "nostalgic").
Infrequent or rare occurrences of "hom" often tied to words like homophobic, homosexuality, or homo but also in words like home, homily, homogeneous, homogen, homing, or homin.

Various forms of the prefix "hom-" which can express different meanings such as similarity (homolog, homage, homophobic), home (homestead, homeschool, homepage), and more, or just forms of the word "home" (homicide, homeschooling, homemaker) and lastly, words ending in -er (homer).

The prefix "hom-" appears in various words, often related to concepts of sameness, similarity, or identity, such as "homogeneous", "homology", "homophobic", "homosexuality", and "homestead". Additionally, words with the prefix "homo-" are also present, such as "homicide". Other words like "homage" and "homers" (as in a home run in baseball) also appear.
The "hom" token is often followed by a suffix, commonly "osexual", "ophobic", "less", "ers", or "ing", forming words such as "homosexual", "homophobic", "homless", "homers", or "homing".
The "hom" token is often followed by a suffix, commonly "osexual", "ophobic", "less", "ers", or "ing", forming words such as "homosexual", "homophobic", "homless", "homers", or "homing".

Adverbs or adjectives with negative or neutral connotation often follow "neither", while nouns often follow the word "neither". Other highlighted words include nouns that have an object-like quality, and words that are associated with electronics or technology, such as "automated", "inx" ( likely referring to an Indilinx drive), "outsole", "freezer", "homophobic", and "blocked".

The token often indicates words that are related to a particular domain or field, such as technology ("phishing", "bug", "hostel", "homophobic", etc.), but also appears in contexts such as ordinal numbers ("Number"), nouns that describe a contained space or relationship ("hostel", "rivalry"), or form a word with a preceding word ("hos", "Gill", "pho").
references to homophobic themes or items
The prefix "Hom" appears to be a significant token, often denoting "homosexuality" or related concepts, and occasionally being part of other words like "homophobic" or "hometown".

Surnames ("Casey", "Spar", "Cob") and words related to energy, human behavior, and societal issues, such as "renewable", "homophobic", "preventative", "inhibitory", and "decorative", often appearing in formal or informative contexts.

Words related to formal or official processes, such as "reporting", "integration", and "informal" or "homophobic" in context, often indicating a formal or technical tone, or used to describe social issues or behaviors.

Proper nouns, specifically locations (e.g. cities, countries) and names of individuals, as well as some common nouns related to food (e.g. falafel) and social classes (e.g. bourgeois), and terms related to social attitudes (e.g. homophobic) and emotions (e.g. inspired).

Adjectives, in particular those with suffixes "-ic", "-ive", "-al", "-ly", "-ous" and "-ful" that are used to describe or modify nouns, often with strong connotations, such as "explosive", "homophobic", "revolutionary", "artistic", "good", "bad", "smart", "offensive", "stressful", "educational" and "terrorist".

Specific terms often related to particular fields or concepts, such as "cognition", "wing" (denoting political orientation), "homophobic", "flooding", "pristine", "indigenous", "graphics", "ary" (in "plenary"), and "SEQ" (denoting sequence), which are often domain-specific or technical.

Nouns related to published materials, such as books, journals, and articles, often denoted as "Publications." Other common nouns include "reprint" and "bookshelf." Additionally, words describing prejudiced behavior or attitudes, including "sexist," "homophobic," and "misuse," appear frequently.
